titleStmt.title: A letter from Amsterdam conteining the full relation of the proceedings of the Prince of Orange against that city, and the transactions betwixt him, and the citizens, their opening of the sluces to drown the said city, with severall other passages thereupon, and the copy of the Prince of Orange his letter the magistrates of the city. With an exact relation of the five days seige or blocking up, of Amsterdam by the Prince of Orange, and Grave William of Nassaw. Together with a particular discovery of the whole design and opening the sluces to let in the sea, which hath overflown great part of the land.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A letter from Amsterdam conteining the full relation of the proceedings of the Prince of Orange against that city, and the transactions betwixt him, and the citizens, their opening of the sluces to drown the said city, with severall other passages thereupon, and the copy of the Prince of Orange his letter the magistrates of the city. With an exact relation of the five days seige or blocking up, of Amsterdam by the Prince of Orange, and Grave William of Nassaw. Together with a particular discovery of the whole design and opening the sluces to let in the sea, which hath overflown great part of the land.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Amsterdam (Netherlands) -- History -- Siege, 1650 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: A Letter from AMSTERDAM Conteining the full relation of the Proceedings of the Prince of Orange Again≈øt that City, and the tran≈øactions betwixt him, and the Citizens, their opening of the Sluces to drown the ≈øaid City, with ≈øeverall other pa≈ø≈øages thereupon, and the Copy of the Prince of Orange his Letter the Magi≈øtrates of the City.
WITH An exact relation of the five days ≈øeige or blocking up, of Am≈øterdam by the Prince of Orange, and Grave William of Na≈ø≈øaw.
TOGETHER With a particular di≈øcovery of the whole de≈øign and opening the Sluces to let in the Sea, which hath over flown great part of the Land.
LONDON Printed by Bernard Al≈øop for T. P. and are to be ≈øold at the Royall-Exchange in Cornhil. 1650.

div.head: Letters from AMSTERDAM CONTEINING The full relation of the Proceedings of the Prince of ORANGE, again≈øt that City, and the tran≈øactions betwixt him and the Citizens, their opening of the Sluces, to drown the ≈øaid City with ≈øeverall other pa≈ø≈øages thereupon, the Copy of the Prince of ORANGE his Letter to the Magi≈øtrates of the City.
div.p:
I Doubt not but the news of the Armies comming down again≈øt Am≈øterdam; hath by this time di≈øper≈øed it ≈øelf throughout Europe, but the occa≈øion and the tran≈øactions between the Prince of Orange, and the Citizens may be worthy of your ob≈øervation, viz. The Prince having a high di≈øplea≈øure
and indgnation again≈øt the Magi≈øtrates of Am≈øterdam contrived away whereby he intended to ≈øurprize this rich & famous City by a ≈øtratagem, and to effect this de≈øign without giving cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpicion what his intent was, He ordred Grave William of Na≈ø≈øaw to empty all frontier Garri≈øons, upon pretence of conveying the old Prince of Orange into Germany, and to be ready at the ≈øame time with his hor≈øe to enter the City, which was contrived to be done on Saturday the thirty of July about 3 or 4 in the morning at the opening of the Gates; for effecting of which de≈øign with the more certainty and ≈øecrecie, about two hundred foot ≈øouldiers were put privately into ≈øeveral Turf boats, which were to come up to the City at the ≈øame time by water, and lying undi≈øcovered, were to fall in at the very ≈øame in≈øtant when the hor≈øe ≈øhould enter the gates, and ≈øurprize the Guard at the Regulaters high-way, which being done, he thought good to make the City without any re≈øi≈øtance. But ≈øo it was, that when the Plot was almo≈øt ready to be put in execution, it plea≈øed God to di≈øappoint al their purpo≈øes, partly by rea≈øon of the great rain which fell all Friday (July 29.) in the afternoon, and all the ≈øame night, which made the ways very deep and rotten; ≈øo that the Prince his hor≈øe having a long march, of four and twenty miles tyred.

Then they turned to a City about ten miles off, but the Citizens refu≈øed to pa≈ø≈øe through or let them in, in regard they knew not what they were; whereupon they were forced to march another way, which was to their great di≈øadvantage, and that nigh
being very dark, and wanting good guides, they mi≈øtook their way, which hindred them above three hours time, by rea≈øon whereof they could not get unto Am≈øterdam before nine of the clock on Saturday, which was ≈øix houres after the time appointed to enter the City, ≈øo that before they got thither, their de≈øign was di≈øcovered to the Magi≈øtrates, by the Po≈øt of Hambrough, who accidentally fel mong≈øt the hor≈øe, when they were doubtfull of their way, which made his company very acceptable to them, in regard they might make u≈øe of him to be their guide, but when he perceived their de≈øign, he ≈øtole away from them and ha≈øted to Am≈øterdam, and made known to the Magi≈øtrates, what he had learned by riding a while among≈øt their troops.

Grave William perceiving that Providence fought again≈øt him (to the lo≈ø≈øe of the time appointed, and be≈øt opportunity) was filled with di≈øcontent, and quartered his Forces at Over-Qirtie, which is three miles from the City, attending there to receive further Orders from the Prince of Orange, who was at the Hague, and had there impri≈øoned many publique per≈øons that were ≈øent from Dort, Horten, Delf, and other places, and ≈øo confident was he, that the de≈øign on which he had ≈øent Grave William, would take effect, that he told the impri≈øoned with his own mouth, Am≈øterdam was his own, but immediately after news was brought him to the contrary, which ≈øo much ≈øtartled him that its ‚Ä¢ aid, he took his hat, threw it one the ground, and ≈øet his feet upon it. When his heat of pa≈ø≈øion was over, he ha≈øted away and on Sunday came to
Grave William, but his comming was to little purpo≈øe, for ≈øo ≈øoon as the Magi≈øtrates of Am≈øterdam, received the information from the Po≈øt at Hamborough as afore≈øaid, they cau≈øed all the gates of the City to be ≈øhut up, and the booms to be lockt, which are as ≈øo many gates by water, and put all the City-Garri≈øon into arms, with their muskets ready charged with bullet, They al≈øo cau≈øed ≈øeverall Bra≈ø≈øe Guns to be mounted on their works, and ≈øent many ve≈ø≈øels well man'd and provided to lie upon Sin≈øter, which is an inland River, and ≈øome men of war rode at Anchor upon the Tij, which is an arm of the Sea, So that good guards were quickly placed about the City, both by land and water, and the apparence of men in their Arms was the more ≈øpeedier for that at the beat of Drum they were commanded forth in the name of the Magi≈øtrates of Am≈øterdam, which was a thing not u≈øuall.

The city being in ≈øuch a po≈øture of defence, Grave William moved the Prince to block up the city at a di≈øtance on the South ≈øide of Tij, conceiving that if they could keep provi≈øions from it, in time he ≈øhould obtain his De≈øires. But the Magi≈øtrates wi≈øely fore≈øeeing the danger, cau≈øed all the Sluces to be opened, on Sunday about noon, it plea≈øed God a little before to turn the wind Northwe≈øt, which u≈øually brings in much water; by this means all the low grounds for many miles without Am≈øterdam lay under water in ≈øhort time, ≈øo that the Princes hor≈øes could have no gra≈ø≈øe, nor make nearer approaches, unle≈ø≈øe upon banks, where above three a bre≈øt could not march
and then it mu≈øt have been upon the mouth of the cannon: hereupon on ≈øunday the Prince ≈øent a Trumpeter into the city, and 4 of the Cities Councel was ≈øent to the Prince at ≈øeveral times, on Munday, Tue≈øday, and Wedne≈øday, and ≈øtayed all Tue≈øday and Wedne≈øday night with him; in all which time ≈øeveral other me≈ø≈øengers came from him to the Magi≈øtrates. During all the≈øe tran≈øactions, ≈øeveral Letters came from the mo≈øt eminent towns in Holland, and from Utritch to the Magi≈øtrates of Am≈øterdam, certifying their di≈ølike of the Princes proceedings, and ≈øeveral other Magi≈øtrates came al≈øo in per≈øon, affirming the ≈øame, which much encouraged the City, and di≈øheartned the Prince, who on Wedne≈øday was commanded by the States General (as is reported) to appear pre≈øently in the Hague, and in four and twenty hours to cau≈øe all the Forces to repair to their ≈øeveral Garri≈øons; and to that end on Thur≈øday morning as ≈øoon as the day appeared, he removed from before Am≈øterdam, at which there was no ≈ømall rejoycing. During the Prince his ab≈øence from the Hague, there hath been mutenies, and the inhabitants would have plundered the Princes Court.
Thus you have a Relation of the 5 days blocking up of the famous City of Am≈øterdam, who in the Hague (no doubt) will pro≈øecute the chief authors of this de≈øign, of which more hereafter.

div.head: A Copy of a Letter ≈øent by his Highne≈øs the the Prince of Orange, to the right wor≈øhipfull the Burgama≈øters, and Governours of the City of Am≈øterdam.
div.p: RIght wor≈øhipfull, wi≈øe, di≈øcreet, and ≈øingular good friends; Being la≈øt time in your Citie, I was ≈øo ≈øtrangly entreated by you, that (to bee no more ≈øubject to the like) I have appointed Count William of Na≈ø≈øaw, with certain Troops in your Citie, with an Order, to keepe all things therein in peace and tranquillity. To the end, that what I have further to propound unto you, touching the ≈øervice of the State, may not be interrupted by ≈øome ill-meaning people: To which J de≈øire you to put too your helping hand. And relying hereupon, we commend you to the protection of the mo≈øt High, and remain,

closer.signed: Your good Friend C. P. d' Orange.
